articles.title: Scientists supercharge solar power 15x with black metal tech
articles.summary: A Rochester team engineered a new type of solar thermoelectric generator that produces 15 times more power than earlier versions. By enhancing heat absorption and dissipation rather than tweaking semiconductor materials, they dramatically improved efficiency and demonstrated practical applications like powering LEDs.
articles.content:
In the quest for energy independence, researchers have studied solar thermoelectric generators (STEGs) as a promising source of solar electricity generation. Unlike the photovoltaics currently used in most solar panels, STEGs can harness all kinds of thermal energy in addition to sunlight. The simple devices have hot and cold sides with semiconductor materials in between, and the difference in temperature between the sides generates electricity through a physical phenomenon known as the Seebeck effect.

But current STEGs have major efficiency limitations preventing them from being more widely adopted as a practical form of energy production. Right now, most solar thermoelectric generators convert less than 1 percent of sunlight into electricity, compared to roughly 20 percent for residential solar panel systems.

That gap in efficiency was dramatically reduced through new techniques developed by researchers at the University of Rochester's Institute of Optics. In a study published in Light: Science and Applications, the team described their unique spectral engineering and thermal management methods to create a STEG device that generates 15 times more power than previous devices.

"For decades, the research community has been focusing on improving the semiconductor materials used in STEGs and has made modest gains in overall efficiency," says Chunlei Guo, a professor of optics and of physics and a senior scientist at Rochester's Laboratory for Laser Energetics. "In this study, we don't even touch the semiconductor materials -- instead, we focused on the hot and the cold sides of the device instead. By combining better solar energy absorption and heat trapping at the hot side with better heat dissipation at the cold side, we made an astonishing improvement in efficiency."

The new, high-efficiency STEGs were engineered with three strategies. First, on the hot side of the STEG, the researchers used a special black metal technology developed in Guo's lab to transform regular tungsten to selectively absorb light at the solar wavelengths. Using powerful femtosecond laser pulses to etch metal surfaces with nanoscale structures, they enhanced the material's energy absorption from sunlight, while also reducing heat dissipation at other wavelengths.

Second, the researchers "covered the black metal with a piece of plastic to make a mini greenhouse, just like on a farm," says Guo. "You can minimize the convection and conduction to trap more heat, increasing the temperature on the hot side."

Lastly, on the cold side of the STEG, they once again used femtosecond laser pulses, but this time on regular aluminum, to create a heat sink with tiny structures that improved the heat dissipation through both radiation and convection. That process doubles the cooling performance of a typical aluminum heat dissipator.

In the study, Guo and his research team provided a simple demonstration of how their STEGS can be used to power LEDs much more effectively than the current methods. Guo says the technology could also be used to power wireless sensors for the Internet of Things, fuel wearable devices, or serve as off-grid renewable energy systems in rural areas.

The National Science Foundation, FuzeHub, and the Goergen Institute for Data Science and Artificial Intelligence supported the research.

This advancement has broad implications for renewable energy generation, potentially benefiting off-grid communities and IoT devices, representing a meaningful step forward in sustainable energy solutions.
articles.personality_title: New solar technology boosts power output 15 times using black metal
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists have been working on solar thermoelectric generators (STEGs), devices that turn heat from the sun into electricity. Unlike regular solar panels, which use sunlight directly, STEGs use the temperature difference between a hot side and a cold side to produce power. However, these devices have been much less efficient than standard solar panels.

**What happened** – A research team at the University of Rochester developed a new STEG that produces 15 times more power than earlier models. Instead of changing the materials that generate electricity, they improved how the device absorbs heat on the hot side and releases heat on the cold side. They used special black metal created by laser etching to absorb more sunlight and trapped heat with a plastic cover like a tiny greenhouse. On the cold side, they used laser-etched aluminum to cool the device better.

**Impact** – This new approach greatly increases the efficiency of STEGs, making them much more useful for real-life applications. The team showed their device could power LED lights better than older versions. This technology could help power devices without wires, like sensors for smart technology or wearable gadgets, and provide electricity in places without easy access to power.

**What's next step** – Researchers plan to explore more practical uses for this improved STEG technology and work on making it easier and cheaper to produce. This could lead to new renewable energy tools for homes, remote areas, and electronic devices.

**One-sentence takeaway** – By improving heat absorption and cooling with black metal and clever design, scientists made solar thermoelectric generators 15 times more powerful than before.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une nouvelle technologie solaire multiplie par 15 la puissance grâce au métal noir
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les scientifiques travaillent sur les générateurs thermoélectriques solaires (GTS), des appareils qui transforment la chaleur du soleil en électricité. Contrairement aux panneaux solaires classiques qui utilisent directement la lumière, les GTS exploitent la différence de température entre un côté chaud et un côté froid pour produire de l’électricité. Mais ces appareils sont beaucoup moins efficaces que les panneaux solaires standards.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Une équipe de recherche de l’Université de Rochester a développé un nouveau GTS qui produit 15 fois plus d’énergie que les modèles précédents. Au lieu de changer les matériaux qui génèrent l’électricité, ils ont amélioré la façon dont l’appareil absorbe la chaleur côté chaud et la dissipe côté froid. Ils ont utilisé un métal noir spécial créé par gravure laser pour capter plus de lumière solaire et ont piégé la chaleur avec une couverture plastique comme une mini-serre. Côté froid, ils ont gravé de l’aluminium pour mieux refroidir l’appareil.

**Impact** – Cette nouvelle méthode augmente beaucoup l’efficacité des GTS, les rendant plus utiles pour des applications concrètes. L’équipe a montré que leur appareil pouvait alimenter des LED bien mieux que les versions anciennes. Cette technologie pourrait aider à alimenter sans fil des capteurs pour la technologie intelligente, des objets portables, ou fournir de l’électricité dans des zones isolées.

**Étape suivante** – Les chercheurs vont étudier des usages pratiques pour cette technologie améliorée et chercher à la rendre plus simple et moins coûteuse à fabriquer. Cela pourrait ouvrir la voie à de nouveaux outils d’énergie renouvelable pour les maisons, les zones éloignées et les appareils électroniques.

**Résumé en une phrase** – En améliorant l’absorption et la dissipation de la chaleur avec du métal noir et un design ingénieux, les scientifiques ont rendu les générateurs thermoélectriques solaires 15 fois plus puissants.
articles.personality_title_es: Nueva tecnología solar aumenta la potencia 15 veces con metal negro
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los científicos han estado trabajando en generadores termoeléctricos solares (GTS), dispositivos que convierten el calor del sol en electricidad. A diferencia de los paneles solares normales, que usan la luz directamente, los GTS aprovechan la diferencia de temperatura entre un lado caliente y otro frío para producir energía. Sin embargo, estos aparatos son mucho menos eficientes que los paneles solares tradicionales.

**Qué pasó** – Un equipo de la Universidad de Rochester desarrolló un nuevo GTS que produce 15 veces más energía que los modelos anteriores. En lugar de cambiar los materiales que generan electricidad, mejoraron cómo el dispositivo absorbe calor en el lado caliente y cómo libera calor en el lado frío. Usaron un metal negro especial creado con grabado láser para captar más luz solar y atraparon el calor con una cubierta plástica como un mini invernadero. En el lado frío, grabaron aluminio para enfriar mejor el dispositivo.

**Impacto** – Este nuevo método aumenta mucho la eficiencia de los GTS, haciéndolos más útiles para aplicaciones prácticas. El equipo demostró que su dispositivo puede alimentar luces LED mejor que las versiones antiguas. Esta tecnología podría ayudar a alimentar sensores inalámbricos para tecnología inteligente, dispositivos que se usan en el cuerpo, o dar electricidad en lugares sin acceso fácil a la red.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores planean explorar más usos prácticos para esta tecnología mejorada y trabajar para hacerla más fácil y barata de fabricar. Esto podría llevar a nuevas herramientas de energía renovable para hogares, áreas remotas y dispositivos electrónicos.

**Resumen en una frase** – Mejorando la absorción y disipación de calor con metal negro y diseño inteligente, los científicos hicieron generadores termoeléctricos solares 15 veces más potentes.
